Package civitas.celestis.graphics

Class LinearColor

java.lang.Object
civitas.celestis.math.vector.Float4
civitas.celestis.graphics.LinearColor
All Implemented Interfaces:
Color8, FloatVector<Float4>, Vector<Float,Float4>, Collectable<Float>, Listable<Float>, Packable32, Packable64, Groupable<Float>, Transformable<Float>, Serializable
public class LinearColor extends Float4 implements Color8
An 8-bit color with 32 bits of precision.

The allowed component range of 0-255 is not enforced by throwing an exception. This is due to the fact that this class is immutable, and arithmetic operations such as linear interpolation (LERP) require re-instantiation. Validating all four components in every constructor call would be very inefficient.

Instead, whether this color is a valid color can be checked by calling isValid(), and should be checked before using this color to render an object. Alternatively, the exception throwing requireValid() can be used as part of a method call chain. Values are automatically clamped to be within the range when converting it to an AWT color, as AWT colors throw exceptions when the components are out of range.

When copying a linear color using the copy constructor, (which should never be done; this class is immutable and copying it achieves nothing) make sure to cast it to Float4 for optimal performance.
final LinearColor colorToCopy;
new LinearColor((Float4) colorToCopy);

See Also:
  • Color8
  • SimpleColor
  • Serialized Form

    • pack24

      public int pack24()
      Packs this color into 24 bits. The alpha component is lost. The return value of this method should be in the following format.

      Bits 16-23 represent the red component of this color as an unsigned byte.
      Bits 8-15 represent the green component of this color as an unsigned byte.
      Bits 0-7 represent the blue component of this color as an unsigned byte.

      Specified by:
      pack24 in interface Color8
      Returns:
      The 24 bit representation of this color
      See Also:
      • Color8.pack24(int, int, int)

    • pack32

      public int pack32()
      Packs this color into 32 bits. The return value of this method should be in the following format.

      Bits 24-31 represent the alpha component of this color as an unsigned byte.
      Bits 16-23 represent the red component of this color as an unsigned byte.
      Bits 8-15 represent the green component of this color as an unsigned byte.
      Bits 0-7 represent the blue component of this color as an unsigned byte.

      This is the same format that the AWT Color class uses.
      Specified by:
      pack32 in interface Color8
      Specified by:
      pack32 in interface Packable32
      Returns:
      The 32 bit representation of this color
      See Also:
      • Color8.pack32(int, int, int, int)

    • pack64

      public long pack64()
      Packs this color into 64 bits. The return value of this method should be in the following format.

      Bits 48-65 represent the red component of this color.
      Bits 32-47 represent the green component of this color.
      Bits 16-31 represent the blue component of this color.
      Bits 0-15 represent the alpha component of this color.

      Specified by:
      pack64 in interface Color8
      Specified by:
      pack64 in interface Packable64
      Returns:
      The 64 bit representation of this color
      See Also:
      • Color8.pack64(float, float, float, float)

    • awt32

      @Nonnull public Color awt32()
      Converts this color into an AWT Color. This packs the color into 32 bits, preserving the alpha component.
      Specified by:
      awt32 in interface Color8
      Returns:
      The AWT representation of this color

    • awt24

      @Nonnull public Color awt24()
      Converts this color into an AWT Color. This packs the color into 24 bits, dropping the alpha component. The alpha value will be 255. (opaque)
      Specified by:
      awt24 in interface Color8
      Returns:
      The AWT representation of this color

    • equals

      public boolean equals(@Nullable Object obj)
      Checks for equality between this vector and the provided object obj. This will check if the other object is also a vector, and then compare the length and components.

      If the two vectors have the same length and every component has the same numerical value, this will return true.

      Specified by:
      equals in interface Color8
      Specified by:
      equals in interface Vector<Float,Float4>
      Overrides:
      equals in class Float4
      Parameters:
      obj - The object to compare to
      Returns:
      true if the other object is also a vector, and they represent the same numerical value
